awd_titl_txt: Metallization of Hydrogen-Rich Materials: Predicting Novel Superconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research and education whose ultimate goal is the rational design via computational modeling of new superconductors, materials through which electric currents can flow without losing energy. Replacing copper wires with superconducting power lines would have a tremendously beneficial impact on the electrical power infrastructure of the USA, but unfortunately all of the superconductors that are technologically useful must be cooled to very low temperatures. Research suggests that hydrogen-rich solids could potentially behave as superconductors at high temperatures and are the focus of this project.

Just like diamonds can be synthesized at high pressures deep within the Earth, researchers can use pressure as a variable to create new materials with unusual properties. A number of superconductors have been synthesized in this way. Recent exciting experiments in certain hydrogen- and lanthanum-containing compounds under pressure bring tantalizing promise of room-temperature superconductivity, exhibiting superconductivity onset temperatures of as high as 44 degrees Fahrenheit. These types of experiments are very difficult to carry out, and accurate computational predictions can accelerate new materials discovery. The PI will carry out calculations based upon quantum mechanics to predict promising new targets for synthesis, and will collaborate with leading experimental groups in high-pressure research that will attempt to create these materials. To advance this goal the PI will further develop relevant software that can be used to computationally predict the structure of a solid without any experimental information. The software is freely available to the materials science, physics, and chemistry communities, facilitating the advance of rational materials design as well as of current and future discoveries in science and engineering.

Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in computational materials discovery as part of this project. Aiming to broaden their participation, undergraduate students from underrepresented groups will be trained in computational modelling and materials prediction via personnel exchange, paving the way for future career opportunities in STEM fields.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research and education that will lead towards rational design of novel superconductors. The PI will computationally predict the crystal structures of materials with unique stoichiometries and structures that can be synthesized under pressure, and study their electronic structure and properties via first-principles calculations. The phase diagrams under pressure of most binary hydrides have already been explored computationally, and a number of phases with very high superconducting critical temperatures have been predicted, in particular for alkaline and rare-earth polyhydrides. The focus of this project will be on ternary hydrides, whose structures and properties are still unknown. The PI will also study novel hydrides containing expanded metal compounds, which are known to exhibit fascinating quantum behavior. New, perhaps completely unexpected, chemistry and totally new types of materials will be discovered theoretically, and the predictions will be confirmed by leading experimental groups in high-pressure research.

The XtalOpt evolutionary algorithm that can be used to predict the structure of an extended system given only its stoichiometry, will be further developed. Key developments will increase the size and complexity of the unit cells that can be predicted without any experimental information, and accelerate the progress of a priori structure prediction for extended systems. The crystallography suite within the highly popular chemical builder, editor, and visualizer Avogadro, will be further advanced. XtalOpt and Avogadro are open-source software, which contributes to the creation of cyberinfrastructure as well as to facilitating current and future discoveries in science and engineering.

Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in rational computational materials design and programming, thereby preparing them for future careers where synergy between theory, computation, and experiment leads to innovation. Collaboration with primarily undergraduate, minority-serving institutions that involves student and faculty exchange will expose students from underrepresented groups to research and future career opportunities in STEM fields and train them in first-principles modelling techniques.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This project is concerned with the development of computational methods and programs, and in particular the XtalOpt evolutionary algorithm for crystal structure prediction, designed to predict new materials that could revolutionize our everyday lives. This includes batteries, energetic materials, superconductors and more. Our focus has been on predicting new superconductors because electricity can pass through them without losing energy to resistance. Unfortunately, the superconducting materials that are currently known cannot be used to replace copper wires since they require cooling to very low temperatures to function. Therefore, substantial effort has been placed into finding a material that could be superconducting at room temperature.

 

Exciting new research has revealed that hydrogen rich solids, under conditions of extreme pressures, can be superconductors at record-breaking high temperatures. The PI and her group have therefore used XtalOpt to predict the structures of compounds containing the elements Ca-S-H, C-S-H, and S-P-H at various pressures and studied their propensity for superconductivity. A number of novel compounds have been predicted with superconducting critical temperatures approaching 100 F. Furthermore, the PI collaborated with experimental groups who synthesized a Y-H compound under pressure that was superconducting at temperatures as high as 12 F to characterize the arrangement of its atoms. The PI wrote a number of review articles on the recent advances in superconductivity, and organized a RoadMap article on superconductivity containing viewpoints from all of the main researchers in this field. Finally, using theoretical computations the PI helped explain why combinations of certain metal atoms with hydrogen result in superconductors with very high critical temperatures under pressure, whereas other metal atoms do not. These results will be useful in designing superconductors that work at lower pressures, and that are chemically more complex than the systems that have been studied to date.

 

In addition, computational studies on a wide range of materials systems including carbon allotropes with superior properties, intermetallics for photovoltaic applications, and battery materials have been performed.

 

Broader Impacts: The PhD students, postdoctoral associates and undergraduate students that have been involved in this research were trained in: computational materials prediction, scientific programming, writing manuscripts, presenting their research visually and orally, and collaboration with experimental groups. They have been exposed to a multi-disciplinary atmosphere and have learned to communicate with scientists that have backgrounds in chemistry, physics, materials science, geo-science and astrophysics preparing them for future STEM careers.

 

The XtalOpt evolutionary algorithm is published under an open-source license thereby enhancing the STEM cyberinfrastructure. The PI and her group members gave numerous tutorials, including to researchers from Primarily Undergraduate Institutions, about how to use XtalOpt to predict new materials.

 

The PI has spoken extensively with science journalists from the New York Times, Scientific American, Chemistry World and many other venues describing the recent breakthroughs in the search for superconductivity. She has given numerous public lectures, including at research universities, conferences, and primarily undergraduate institutions on her research.

 

The PI worked with the American Physical Society to establish a new award for Early Career researchers named after the famous physicists Neil Ashcroft. She was elected to the Chair Line of the American Physical Society Division of Materials Research (a 4 yr term) and has served on various awards committees as well as helped to organize the society?s annual March meeting.
